paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted information on the TTR gene variant V122I, including penetrance data and individual records.

patients.demographics: Individuals over the age of 65, primarily African American
patients.phenotype: Senile systemic amyloidosis (SSA) and cardiac TTR deposits

individual_records.phenotype_details: Cardiomyopathy due to TTR amyloid deposits
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The V122I mutation that alters the stability of transthyretin (TTR) affects 3–4% of African Americans and leads to amyloidogenesis and development of cardiomyopathy.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Cardiac TTR deposits with symptoms of heart failure
individual_records.evidence_sentence: In addition, 10–15% of individuals over the age of 65 develop senile systemic amyloidosis (SSA) and cardiac TTR deposits due to wild-type TTR amyloidogenesis.
As no approved therapies for TTR amyloid cardiomyopathy are available, the development of drugs that prevent amyloid-mediated cardiotoxicity is desired.

individual_records.phenotype_details: No symptoms, monitored for potential onset
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Several of these ligands stabilized TTR in human serum more effectively than diflunisal.

functional_data.summary: The V122I variant leads to destabilization of TTR, promoting amyloid formation.

variants.segregation_data: Segregates with disease in families, particularly in African American populations.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on population studies and functional assays.
variants.additional_notes: The study emphasizes the need for therapies targeting TTR stabilization.
key_quotes: The V122I mutation that alters the stability of transthyretin (TTR) affects 3–4% of African Americans and leads to amyloidogenesis and development of cardiomyopathy.
10–15% of individuals over the age of 65 develop senile systemic amyloidosis (SSA) and cardiac TTR deposits due to wild-type TTR amyloidogenesis.

extraction_metadata.notes: Data was extracted from the main text, with a focus on the TTR gene variant V122I.
